replies.author: noblepaul

replies.bodyText:
This try/catch is inside a loop that makes requests to ZooKeeper. So you are saying that if the thread is interruped (shutdown, or in tests for example) the plan is to swallow that interruption and continue processing (doing requests to ZooKeeper for every child this zkpath has, with sleeps/retries), and the intention of that is to add an "exception" to one (just one) of the elements in the tree in the response?
Regarding other exceptions, lets say you are getting back a SessionExpiredException, the plan is to continue iterating over all the child docs and continue adding node -> KeeperException.SessionExpiredException?
I think the proper handling of most these exceptions is to stop processing and return an error. If you get a NoNodeException, then yes, that could be added in the response if you want, but doing a blind catch (Exception e) is a bad idea.
replies.author: tflobbe

replies.bodyText:
Please take a look at the latest

Other Exceptions return with 500

This is supposed to just fail fast if there is a problem. It does not need to be any more sophisticated than that
